awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Redeployable Spread Spectrum Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) Meteor Radar
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to construct a novel meteor radar instrument called  Multistatic Spread Spectrum Meteor Radar (MSMR). The MSMR design is innovative in part because the electronics would be based upon commercial components that would avoid radio wave interference problems.  The primary purpose of the application of this new instrument is to study the phenomena of mesospheric dynamics, ionospheric irregularities, and meteoroid influx deposition. The primary aim of the science application using this instrument would be to achieve the measurements of the winds in the mesosphere-lower thermosphere region from 75 to 110 km. Unlike other meteor radar systems, this instrument would be easily transportable, cheap to fabricate, with relatively low power required for any radio transmission. The broader impact of this award is that it would provide an excellent platform for young engineers to gain experience in working with a design structure largely centered around the collection of immense amounts of data that is analyzed on the fly to achieve intermediate data products. Summer students would be supported on this project as well as a postdoctoral scholar that would receive part time support.

The radar system will consist of three transmitter antennas and two interferometric receiver antenna fields.  A continuous pseudorandom phasecode unique to each transmitter would be utilized for transmission of the radar signals. Because pseudorandom waveforms do not correlate with external radio interference, the system has good rejection of external radio interference.  An unqiue property of MSMR that is unlike any existing meteor radars is all of the transmitter antennas of MSMR can be operated on the same frequency band with minimal mutual interference. The radar system can also be used at a smaller peak power than current systems, while utilizing the same average power as a pulsed system. The new innovations make radio licensing easier, as a large radar network will only occupy a portion of the radio spectrum that is equivalent to a single mono-static radar. These new MSMR features allow construction of a dense meteor radar network that can be applied to studies of mesospheric wind fields and trajectories of ablating meteoroids using a significantly larger number of specular meteor echoes than ever before. The radar can also be used to allow observations of field aligned ionospheric irregularities (FAI) without the range-Doppler ambiguity that is an issue for existing pulsed systems. The radar system relies on modern software defined radio hardware, which greatly reduces the complexity of the radar system, with most of the features implemented in software.

por.por_cntn:
This project made significant progress in developing techniques to observe meteor trails and estimate winds in the upper atmosphere from about 80 to 110 km altitude using radar. Meteoroids present in the solar system, essentially space dust, constantly enter and burn up in the Earth’s atmosphere when their paths intersect. Each meteoroid briefly creates a trail of plasma in the upper atmosphere that can reflect radio waves, and observing this trail with a radar is one of the few ways that we can monitor the meteoroid population. Since meteor trails drift with the wind in the upper atmosphere, they also provide one of the few ways that we can regularly measure winds at that altitude. Standard meteor radars see only a small fraction of the meteors present in a region because most of the meteor trails reflect the transmitted radio wave in a direction other than to the receiver. They are also blind to any wind component that rotates around the radar. This techniques developed by this project address both of these problems by enabling more meteors to be observed in a given region and making it possible to estimate the wind field of the entire region at meteor altitudes. Benefits include a much better capability to observe meteoroid properties and their input to the physics of the upper atmosphere and the ability to study the connection between physical processes in the atmosphere and those in near-Earth space through regular monitoring of upper atmospheric winds.

The specific techniques and technologies advanced by this project include: 1) design and analysis of a multistatic, continuous-wave (CW), pseudorandom-coded radar network that uses multiple transmitters in concert with multiple receivers, 2) software to detect and estimate the parameters of meteors from the multistatic coded CW radar data, and 3) a method based on Gaussian process regression for estimating a wind field from the line-of-sight wind measurements at sporadic locations as provided by meteor reflections. We built a multistatic coded CW radar network called SIMONe (Spread-spectrum Interferometric Meteor Observation Network) in northern Germany, near existing systems for comparison and collaboration, to test these techniques. In an observation campaign we ran at the end of the project, we measured about 150,000 meteors in one day within a region with a radius of approximately 250 km (compare to about 15,000 detections/day within a 150 km radius region with a standard meteor radar). From such measurements, we are able to estimate winds in the upper atmosphere with a spatial resolution of about 20 km horizontally and 2 km vertically and a temporal resolution of about 30 minutes. More importantly, we can quantify the errors of such estimates and know which data can be trusted and which cannot. Based on these techniques, we envision blanketing the globe with a multistatic coded CW meteor radar network to observe the majority of meteoroids entering the atmosphere and continuously monitor upper-atmospheric winds, in the process revolutionizing our knowledge of physical processes near the edge of space.
